awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Data-Driven Models for Biological Dynamics
awd_abstract_narration:
The living cell is an active environment where large biological molecules (such as proteins or DNA) move, collide and react. Current experiments observe these processes indirectly in living systems and as a result, interpreting data from indirect observation is a key challenge in understanding and mathematically describing what happens inside cells. The proposed work will contribute to the development of quantitative biology by considering how data-driven models can be inferred from currently available experimental data. This modeling will produce novel theoretical frameworks to capture how the diffusion of biomolecules and their fluctuating shapes ultimately sustain life. Activities focused on the intersection of biology and physics will be undertaken with the goal of advancing science literacy. A new introductory course in biophysics will be developed for a wide audience, and several outreach activities will be undertaken. Undergraduate and high school students will be engaged in the research through the American Chemical Society Project SEED, with special emphasis placed on recruiting women and students from underprivileged backgrounds. A Summer Camp Program (for ages 8-12) will be held at the Indianapolis Zoo on the subject "The Bacterial Serengeti: exploring the bacterial fauna".
 
The project has two overall goals: 1) Extracting models of conformational dynamics of single molecules (from single molecule force spectroscopy) that will help go beyond the Markov model paradigm and characterize conformational memory of biomolecules linking dynamics and function in nascent chains, folded proteins under varying conditions, as well as active (ATP-hydrolyzing) motors; 2) Developing data-driven frameworks for intracellular anomalous diffusion in the complex crowded cellular environment directly from fluorescence correlation spectroscopy.

This award is supported jointly by the Cellular Dynamics and Function program in the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences and by the Physics of Living Systems program in the Division of Physics.
org_div_long_name: Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences

por.por_cntn:
Briefly, we proposed to develop data-driven methods for the analysis of molecular events resolved down to the level of single molecules. Our thoughts were inspired by early developments in data-driven modeling and our proposal, written in 2015, appeared on the eve of the Data Science revolution that heralded tremendous progress on the mathematical and algorithmic front that we could successfully leverage. Indeed, capturing dynamical events with single molecule resolution requires that we directly confront the fundamental and unavoidable noise sources that stands in the way of interpreting data. 

In particular, we supported a number of undergraduate and graduate students and postdocs who moved onto the next step of their career with a deeper appreciation of rigorous data analysis tools.

Toward addressing our intellectual merits, we published 11 papers many of which tackled problems known for decades to the scientific community but for which an answer was still lacking. This is, in part, because the tools of data analysis were yet to be developed. For instance, in a popular microscopy technique called confocal microscopy we learned how to directly assess the dynamics of individual molecules from the rawest form of data available, a single light particle (photon). Getting to the point where the behavior of individual molecules is assessed is critical toward understanding life at the level of the key actors which dictate its more elemental processes. Our work stands in sharp contrast to methods today which, in an effort to average out the noise, unwittingly average over the behavior of individual molecules thereby eliminating the possibility to explore life at the level at which it unravels. 

Individual molecules, such as DNA and proteins, are essential to the formation of the basic unit of life: cells. While much of our research focus was aimed at capturing events occurring within cells, our outreach was aimed at developing a taste for science in K-12 starting from cells with a special emphasis on the emerging phenomenon of bacterial predation.  For example, we organized a summer camps at the Indianapolis zoo where we prepared activities for K-12 children directly exposing them to quantitative notions relevant to the biophysical sciences. We continued this effort at the Phoenix zoo where we cultivated desert bacteria as well as bacterial predators. We monitored them under the microscope providing a direct means for children to appreciate both the phenomena of predation and adaptations of bacteria to the desert climate. 

 


Last Modified: 04/28/2022
Modified by: Steve Presse
